communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

[Your Name]
[Your Address]
[City, State, Zip Code]
[Email Address]
[Phone Number]
[Date]

[Agency Name]
[Agency Address]
[City, State, Zip Code]
[Email Address]

Subject: Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) Request

Dear [Agency FOIA Officer]:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) (5 U.S.C. § 552), I hereby request access to and copies of the following records:

[Include detailed points about the records you are requesting here]

In accordance with the FOIA and relevant case law, I kindly request that you do not withhold, redact, or delete any records or portions of records unless there is a specific and legitimate exemption under the FOIA. Please note the following key cases addressing FOIA issues:

NLRB v. Robbins Tire & Rubber Co. (437 U.S. 214, 242 [1978]): An agency cannot withhold, redact, or delete records without a specific and legitimate FOIA exemption.
Department of the Air Force v. Rose (425 U.S. 352, 381 [1976]): An agency must provide access to reasonably segregable portions of a record that are not exempt from disclosure.
EPIC v. DOJ (15-1313, D.C. Cir. 2017): An agency has the burden of justifying any withholdings under FOIA.
Phillippi v. CIA (546 F.2d 1009 [D.C. Cir. 1976]): The origin of the "Glomar response," which permits an agency to refuse to confirm or deny the existence of records in certain situations.
If you determine that any portion of the requested records is exempt from disclosure, please provide an itemized list of those exemptions and cite the specific legal basis for each exemption under the FOIA. Additionally, I request that you release any reasonably segregable portions of the records that are not exempt from disclosure.

In light of the court decisions cited above, please be aware that I am prepared to pursue legal action to compel the release of the requested records if they are unlawfully withheld, redacted, or deleted. It is my hope that we can resolve this request amicably and without the need for litigation.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Jordan Lassiter

title: Request for Historical Records on Fishkill Encampment and American Revolution Bicentennial Memorial

communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

Fishkill Town Clerk
807 Route 52, Room 114
Fishkill, NY 12524

Subject: Freedom of Information Law (FOIL) Request

Dear Fishkill Town Clerk:

Pursuant to the New York State Freedom of Information Law (FOIL) (Article 6 of the Public Officers Law), I hereby request access to and copies of the following records:

Documents, maps, and photographs related to the planning, design, construction, and dedication of the American Revolution Bicentennial Memorial in Fishkill, NY, including any records of public meetings or correspondence discussing the memorial.

Historical accounts, personal letters, or diary entries from the time of the Fishkill Encampment that provide firsthand perspectives on the events and daily life at the encampment.

Records of archaeological studies, surveys, or excavations conducted at the site of the Fishkill Encampment, including any findings, reports, or artifacts uncovered during such investigations.

Geographic Information System (GIS) data, maps, and any other relevant spatial data related to the American Revolution Bicentennial Memorial and the Fishkill Encampment, including historical maps that show the layout of the encampment and its surrounding area during the Revolutionary War.

Documents related to the preservation and maintenance of the Fishkill Encampment site and the American Revolution Bicentennial Memorial, including any records of grants, funding sources, or partnerships with preservation organizations.

Any educational materials, brochures, or pamphlets produced by the town or local historical organizations about the American Revolution Bicentennial Memorial and the Fishkill Encampment, intended for public distribution or use in local schools.

In accordance with the FOIL and relevant case law, including Westchester Rockland Newspapers v. Kimball (50 NY2d 575, 581 [1980]), I kindly request that you do not withhold, redact, or delete any records or portions of records unless there is a specific and legitimate exemption under the New York State FOIL. Furthermore, please note that the Court of Appeals in Gould v. New York City Police Department (89 NY2d 267, 277 [1996]) held that an agency must provide access to reasonably segregable portions of a record that are not exempt from disclosure.

If you determine that any portion of the requested records is exempt from disclosure, please provide an itemized list of those exemptions and cite the specific legal basis for each exemption under the New York State FOIL. Additionally, I request that you release any reasonably segregable portions of the records that are not exempt from disclosure.

Please be aware that I am prepared to pursue legal action to compel the release of the requested records if they are unlawfully withheld, redacted, or deleted. It is my hope that we can resolve this request amicably and without the need for litigation.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Jordan Lassiter

communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the New Jersey Open Public Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

Documents regarding the "atrocious assault and battery" investigated by the Morristown Police Department and reported to the FBI on September 28, 1961.

An FBI memo from 1962 mentions that on the above date, a Morristown detective told the Bureau about someone arrested "on charges of atrocious assault and battery...The detective advised that on [DATE REDACTED], a call was received from the landlady at [ADDRESS REDACTED] reporting that a man had been found in a room severely beaten. This man was subsequently identified as [NAME REDACTED] later turned himself into the Morristown, New Jersey, Police Department, at which time he could not be interviewed because of his emotional condition...A doctor was called and [NAME REDACTED] was given sedatives and transferred to the Morristown County Jail."

You may find a copy of the memo attached below.

I am requesting the police report from that incident and any written communication to the FBI in September 1961.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

title: Children in New York "start their day going to the corner bodega, buying cannabis and fentanyl."

communications.subject: New York Freedom of Information Law Request: Children in New York "start their day going to the corner bodega, buying cannabis and fentanyl."
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the New York Freedom of Information Law, I hereby request the following records:

Any and all records in the Department's possession that mention, describe, or pertain to the recent claims by the Mayor of New York City that cannabis products are contaminated with fentanyl and being purchased by children in New York City.  These records would be within the Department's Subject Matter List, headings "Mental Health & Drug/Alcohol Surveillance & Programs" and "Poison Control Center."

The specific quote by the Mayor about children is that "they start their day going to the corner bodega, buying cannabis and fentanyl." See @theRecount. 2023. “‘[Kids] Start Their Day Going to the Corner Bodega, Buying Cannabis and Fentanyl ... They Look at TikTok, That’s Teaching Them How to Steal Cars.’ — NYC Mayor Eric Adams (D) Echoes GOP Talking Points While Speaking at the National Day of Prayer Conference".” Twitter. May 4, 2023. https://twitter.com/therecount/status/1654198878781034502.

Should there exist any record that an actual child in New York City has started their day, specifically purchasing with a cannabis product contaminated with fentanyl, please only provide that record. 

In the absence of such a specific record, I request any and all records of the Department of Health and Mental Hygiene with regard to *any* part of the claim, regardless of whether it is actual or merely rumored, so long as it involves cannabis products contaminated with fentanyl.  That is, any and all records that fit the following bullet point descriptions should be treated as responsive:

* Records mentioning, describing, or pertaining to the existence (actual or merely rumored) of cannabis products contaminated with fentanyl;
* Records mentioning, describing, or pertaining to the existence (actual or merely rumored) of cannabis products contaminated with fentanyl that are possessed or available for purchase;
* Records mentioning, describing, or pertaining to the existence (actual or merely rumored) of cannabis products contaminated with fentanyl that are possessed or available for purchase by children;
* Records mentioning, describing, or pertaining to the existence (actual or merely rumored) of cannabis products contaminated with fentanyl that are possessed or available for purchase in New York City;
* Records mentioning, describing, or pertaining to the existence (actual or merely rumored) of cannabis products contaminated with fentanyl that are possessed or available for purchase in New York City by children. 

Please note: in a February 2023 press conference, the Mayor specifically authorized the speedy public release of information about this claim, as quoted here: "We'll give a list of what we are finding and what they are mixed with, if it is fentanyl or others. So I'll have the N.Y.P.D. give a list of what we're finding in it. We'll get that to you today." (see “Transcript: Mayor Eric Adams Announces Joint Efforts to Combat Proliferation of Illegal, Unlicensed Cannabis Dispensaries.” 2023. The Official Website of the City of New York. February 2023. https://www.nyc.gov/office-of-the-mayor/news/096-23/transcript-mayor-eric-adams-joint-efforts-combat-proliferation-illegal-unlicensed.)

As the Mayor specifically alludes to evidence of his claims and specifically authorizes its release, there are no grounds for citing public safety exemptions to FOIL in withholding a record such as law enforcement secrecy or ongoing investigation. Please note that the a document marked"For Official Use Only" has no special classified status under the law and should be released.  

Disclosure of these records will serve the public interest of avoiding bodegas selling cannabis with fentanyl contamination, evaluating the truth of statements regarding fentanyl and understanding the current state of the War on Drugs. This public good should be evaluated before the withholding of documents or redaction citing privacy interests. 

Under New York State FOIL, wrongful withholding of information may give rise to a lawsuit under Article 78 proceeding in which the agency will be expected to pay reasonable attorney's fees to gain its compliance with the law.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

T. McElwee

This includes any resumes, applications, any job recommendations, promotions, professional license credentials and verification records. Please include a work/salary history. communications.subject: FOIA Request :: N013644-050423
communications.communication:
Dear Anthony: 
 
Thank you for your interest in Chicago Public Schools. Your FOIA request has been received and is being processed. Your FOIA Center reference number for tracking purposes is: N013644-050423 
You have requested the following records: To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Illinois Freedom of Information Act., I hereby request the following records:

school-level budgets for FY24, exported from the EPM budget management software in a tabular format (preferably Excel spreadsheet). Please use the same report view that was provided to school principals. If it is easier to export all schools in one file, that's fine, as long as line items are still filterable by school id.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Anthony Moser

Upload documents directly: https://accounts.muckrock.com/accounts/login/?next=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.muckrock.com%2Faccounts%2Flogin%2F%3Fnext%3D%252Faccounts%252Fagency_login%252Fchicago-public-schools-3121%252Fcps-school-level-budgets-fy24-145365%252F%253F&url_auth_token=AAATZ1CCn_QB9jem9PQylx6L91s%3A1pulvh%3AOo61UD7I6kWBuZ5DOSshIpPT31zK0BKjb1xfvHzh9NE 
 
Chicago Public Schools (CPS) responds to all public records requests in accordance with the Illinois Freedom of Information Act (FOIA), 5 ILCS 140/1 et seq. 
If further time is needed to assemble and copy all documents responsive to your FOIA request, we will contact you with a time estimate and a request to extend. 
Upon the completion of a response, CPS will provide the first 50 pages to you at no charge.  If a response is more than 50 pages, a fee of 15¢ per page will be charged for each additional page. Copies of video recordings have a fee of $48. All applicable fees must be paid prior to the copying. CPS will inform you of any fees due if your paper response exceeds 50 pages. You can monitor the progress of your request at the link below and you’ll receive an email when your request has been completed. Thank you for using the CPS FOIA Center.

communications.subject: Texas Public Information Act Request: McLennan County Administrator Justin Chapman
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Texas Public Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

DWI videos from the last two DWI's that ended in the conviction of Sherre Johnston. Ms. Johnston is in the penitentary and the cases have been disposed of making the DWI videos and other information, such as officer reports, blood alcohol or breath test results available. I would also like all FIVE dash cam videos from the Sheriff's department from the disposed of by dismissal case against Sherre Johnston for the burglary of a habitation, which was Truman Simons' house. There are videos and reports from this that are now available under the Open Records Act that I am entitled to that will be very interesting to the public. Also, all officer reports from the burglary of a habitation, i.e. the Simons' house. In the public interest I am asking for ALL videos and audios of this event and the two DWI's. Thank you.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Bernadette Feazell

communications.subject: New York Freedom of Information Law Request: Fentanyl-laced cannabis
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the New York Freedom of Information Law, I hereby request the following records:

Any record in possession of the Office of Cannabis Management as of May 1, 2023 mentioning or describing the existence of cannabis laced with fentanyl or which warns about cannabis laced with fentanyl. 

Attached, please find a PDF describing an event where Mayor Eric Adams has publicly stated that there is cannabis laced with fentanyl being sold to children in bodegas in New York City. The Mayor having disclosed this information publicly, there is no basis to cite law enforcement secrecy or "For Official Use Only" markings. The examination of this claim and its source is a matter of public interest which outweighs virtually all claims of an interest in withholding records.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

T. McElwee

communications.subject: New York Freedom of Information Law Request: Records of Fentanyl-laced Cannabis
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the New York Freedom of Information Law, I hereby request the following records:

Any record in possession of the Office of Mayor as of May 1, that was received from any law enforcement agency at any time between the date of January 1, 2022 until April 30, 2023, that mentions or describes the existence of cannabis laced with fentanyl or which warns about cannabis laced with fentanyl. 

A list of possible sources of this information (that is neither exhaustive nor exclusive) may include intelligence bulletins published by the New York City Police Department, the New York State Police, the NYC Special Narcotics Prosecutor's Office,  the U.S. Drug Enforcement Administration, the Office of National Drug Control Policy, the Department of Homeland Security, and/or the New York/New Jersey HIDTA. 

Attached, please find a PDF describing an event where the Mayor has publicly stated his knowledge that there is cannabis laced with fentanyl being sold to children.

As the Mayor has repeatedly alluded to the existence of cannabis laced with fentanyl at New York City bodegas, the Office of Mayor has waived any right to invoke law enforcement secrecy, or cite For Official Use Only/"FOUO" markings (that have no legal standing) or similar exceptions to FOIL. 

There is no forseeable harm in disclosing a document claiming that cannabis is laced with fentanyl, and the examination of these records as well as the source of the claim that cannabis is laced with fentanyl is a matter of ongoing public concern. As such, there is no legal reason to withhold the requested records.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

T. McElwee

title: Central Park Five Case Records (New York City Police Department)

communications.subject: New York Freedom of Information Law Request: Central Park Five Case Records (New York City Police Department)
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the New York Freedom of Information Law, I hereby request the following records:

I am requesting access to and copies of records related to the Central Park Five case. This case is of great public interest as it involved the wrongful convictions of five teenagers - Antron McCray, Kevin Richardson, Yusef Salaam, Raymond Santana, and Korey Wise - for the assault and rape of Trisha Meili, a female jogger, in Central Park on the night of April 19, 1989. The case garnered significant media attention and raised serious concerns about the criminal justice system, police tactics, and racial bias. The convictions were later vacated in 2002, and a settlement was reached with the City of New York in 2014.

Specifically, I am seeking the following records:

All internal memos, emails, and communications related to the investigation of the Central Park Five case.
All documents and records pertaining to the investigation, arrest, and prosecution of Antron McCray, Kevin Richardson, Yusef Salaam, Raymond Santana, and Korey Wise, including but not limited to police reports, witness statements, interrogation records, and forensic evidence.
All records of any internal investigations, disciplinary actions, or reviews related to the handling of the Central Park Five case, including any assessments or evaluations of the tactics employed during the investigation and interrogation process.
Any documents or records that detail the settlement and/or restitution process for Antron McCray, Kevin Richardson, Yusef Salaam, Raymond Santana, and Korey Wise.
All documents and records pertaining to the investigation and prosecution of Matias Reyes, whose confession and DNA evidence ultimately led to the exoneration of the Central Park Five.
Any other relevant documents, records, or files that pertain to the Central Park Five case.
I request that you provide these records without redaction or withholding, as the requested documents are of significant public interest and concern. If any information is withheld or redacted, please provide a written explanation for the denial, citing the specific exemption(s) under FOIL that justify the withholding or redaction. As established in numerous FOIL cases, including Matter of Gould v. New York City Police Department (89 N.Y.2d 267) and Matter of Fink v. Lefkowitz (47 N.Y.2d 567), the burden of proof for denying access to requested documents falls on the agency.

Please be aware that I intend to exhaust all administrative remedies and may seek judicial review under Article 78 of the Civil Practice Law and Rules if access to the requested documents is denied or if there is an unreasonable delay in providing the requested documents.

If you have any questions or need clarification regarding this request, please   feel free to reach out  for clarfication

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Jordan Lassiter

communications.subject: Freedom of Information Act Request: Untitled
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

Requested Info:

On behalf of my non-profit organizational employer, Capital Area Immigrants' Rights (CAIR) Coalition, I request all the data and documents reviewed and utilized by the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) Office of the Inspector General (OIG) in preparing Table 2 of the report titled "ICE Faces Barriers in Timely Repatriation of Detained Aliens" and dated March 11, 2019. https://www.oig.dhs.gov/sites/default/files/assets/2019-03/OIG-19-28-Mar19.pdf 

The report includes a "case review of 3,053 aliens not removed within 90 days of receiving a final order of removal," based on a snapshot of case dispositions as of March 24, 2018. On page 28, in Appendix C, "Results of Electronic File Case Review," there is a table titled "Table 2: Snapshot Case Dispositions." The source for Table 2 is identified as: “OIG Analysis of Aliens Detained Longer than 90 Days Post Final Order of Removal, from ICE ENFORCE Alien Removal Module, ICE Law Enforcement Systems and Analysis case disposition information as of March 24, 2018.” 

I request all the "case disposition information" from the "Aliens Detained Longer than 90 Days Post Final Order of Removal" section within the ICE ENFORCE Alien Removal Module, in its original form as provided to OIG for purposes of the report. In addition, I request all documents and/or tables created by OIG in the course of conducting its "[a]nalysis" of the aforementioned data.

Request for Waiver of Fees:

CAIR Coalition requests that ICE waive all fees associated with this request. Such a request is warranted on the grounds that disclosure of the information contained in the requested record is in the public interest and is “likely to contribute significantly to public understanding of the operations or activities of the government and is not primarily in the commercial interest of the requestor.” 5 U.S.C. § 552(a)(4)(A)(iii); 28 C.F.R. § 16.10(k)(1). Disclosure of this information is in the public interest of understanding in what circumstances ICE will continue to detain non-citizens after 90 days of post-removal order detention. As previously indicated, CAIR Coalition is a nonprofit organization recognized as a 501(c)(3) entity by the Internal Revenue Service that provides legal services and information to immigrant populations and information to the public on immigration issues.  

Disclosure of the requested information also will contribute to “understanding of a reasonably broad audience of persons.” 28 C.F.R. § 16.10(k)(2)(ii)(B). The requested information will be used to better equip pro bono practitioners—both at CAIR Coalition and at other pro bono organizations assisting detained non-citizens in similar circumstances. As a provider of legal services to detained non-citizens, CAIR Coalition has the necessary expertise, capacity, and intention to review, analyze, and synthesize this information and make it accessible to a broad audience of attorneys and clients in immigration proceedings. In addition to the requested information being publicly available on Muckrock, the platform through which I am filing this FOIA request, CAIR Coalition has the capacity to convey the information to a broad audience on CAIR Coalition's website, which receives more than 10,000 monthly visitors. CAIR Coalition also will circulate a summary of information disclosed through this request on its listservs, in which approximately 2,500 attorneys participate. Additionally, CAIR Coalition shares information in its newsletter, which is directly distributed to 6,000 recipients. 

CAIR Coalition is also “a representative of the news media” within the meaning of the statute and applicable regulations. See 5 U.S.C. § 552(a)(4)(A)(ii) (defined as “any . . . entity that gathers information of potential interest to a segment of the public, uses its editorial skills to turn the raw materials into a distinct work, and distributes that work to an audience,”); Nat. Sec. Archive v. Dep’t of Defense, 880 F.2d 1381, 1397 (D.C. Cir. 1989) (same); Electronic Privacy Info. Ctr. v. Dep’t of Defense, 241 F. Supp. 2d 5 (D.D.C. 2003) (non-profit that published information in a wide variety of sources on topics of privacy and civil liberties qualified as representative of news media for FOIA purposes). Given that FOIA's fee waiver requirements are to be “liberally construed in favor of waivers for noncommercial requesters,” a waiver of all fees is justified and warranted in this instance. See Judicial Watch, Inc. v. Rossotti, 326 F.3d 1309, 1312 (D.C. Cir. 2003) (quotation omitted). 

Request for Expedited Processing: 

CAIR Coalition requests Track 1 expedited treatment for this FOIA request. There is a compelling need for expedited processing, namely, an “urgency to inform the public concerning the actual or alleged Federal Government activity.” 5 U.S.C. § 552(a)(6)(E)(v)(II). CAIR Coalition is aware of at least ten individuals who are currently detained by ICE past the 90-day removal period, including four detained after being granted withholding of removal or protection under the Convention Against Torture. These individuals need information about ICE’s policies and practices in order to understand the basis for their detention and advocate for their release.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Ian Austin Rose
